One gripe though is that Blosc.jl doesn't work on SubArrays.

```julia> Blosc.compress(@view A[1:1024])
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching compress(::SubArray{UInt8,1,Array{UInt8,1},Tuple{UnitRange{Int64}},true})
Closest candidates are:
  compress(::Ptr{T}, ::Integer; kws...) where T at C:\Users\kittisopikulm\.julia\dev\Blosc\src\Blosc.jl:105
  compress(::DenseArray; kws...) at C:\Users\kittisopikulm\.julia\dev\Blosc\src\Blosc.jl:111
  compress(::AbstractString; kws...) at C:\Users\kittisopikulm\.julia\dev\Blosc\src\Blosc.jl:115
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope at REPL[151]:1```

attachments.fallback:
[March 19th, 2021 8:50 PM] markkitt: I have new appreciation for how easy Blosc.jl is to use.

Today someone asked me for help with python-blosc. For `a` a NumPy array, the most efficient compression call apparently looks like this:
```blosc.compress_ptr(a.__array_interface__['data'][0], a.size, a.dtype.itemsize, 9,cname= 'lz4')```
I think numcodecs is probably easier to use, but this was a bit shocking.
